com.researchenv.jet.executor

Class Executor<T extends java.lang.Object & java.lang.Runnable>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.researchenv.jet.executor.Executor<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The class type to run on executor. The class will be returned by a listener after execution is finished.

    public class Executor<T extends java.lang.Object & java.lang.Runnable>
extends java.lang.Object
    Executor runs runnable classes in parallel, with a maximum defined number of threads at time.

    Using Executor class to run native programs with NativeProcess

    Simple usage

    1. Create a class which implements Runnable to execute your calculation

     public class Sum implements Runnable{
     private final int x;
     private final int y;
     private int res;
     
     public Sum(int x, int y){
         this.x=x;
         this.y=y;
     }
     
     @Override
     public void run() {
         //Do the work here.
         res=x+y;
     }
         
     int getResult(){
         //Return the result of calculation here.
         return res;
     }
 }

    2. Create an Executor to run Sum class

     import com.researchenv.exptools.executor.Executor;
 
 public class Main {
      public static void main(String[] args) {
          
          //Create the Executor to run your class (Sum)
          //Maximum threads running in parallel is 3 
          Executor<Sum> executor = new Executor<>(3);
 
          //Set the executor's FinishedListener
          executor.setFinishedListener(new FinishedListener<Sum>() {
              @Override
              public void finished(Sum source) {
                  //this is called when a thread is finished
                  System.out.println("Thread finished: result=" +source.getResult());
              }
          });

          //Add instances of your class (Sum)
          Sum s1 = new Sum(1,2);
          Sum s2 = new Sum(2,3);
          Sum s3 = new Sum(4,5);
          Sum s4 = new Sum(0,42);

          executor.add(s1);
          executor.add(s2));
          executor.add(s3));
          executor.add(s4));
 
          //Start the executor
          executor.start();

          //Blocs the execution until all executor threads is finished (optional)
          executor.waitForFinished();
      }
 }

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      int MAX_AVAILABLE_PROCESSORS
      The max number of available processors.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Executor(int maxThreads)
      Create an executor to run Runnable objects in separated threads.

    • Field Detail

      • MAX_AVAILABLE_PROCESSORS

        public final int MAX_AVAILABLE_PROCESSORS
        The max number of available processors.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Executor

        public Executor(int maxThreads)
        Create an executor to run Runnable objects in separated threads. The minimum allowed threads number is 1. The maxThreads can't exceed the number of available processors. The maximum number of processor are stored in Executor.MAX_AVAILABLE_PROCESSORS;
        Parameters:
        maxThreads - Maximum number of threads running at same time. I doesn't exceed the machine maximum number of available processors.
        Since:
        1.0.0

    • Method Detail

      • add

        public void add(T runnable)
        Add a Runnable object to Executor list. Each object will run in a separated thread. Does nothing after Executor.start() is called.
        Parameters:
        runnable - A Runnable object to run.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • setFinishedListener

        public void setFinishedListener(FinishedListener<T> finishedListener)
        Set a listener to the executor. The listener is called every time a Runnable finishes execution.
        Parameters:
        finishedListener - A finished listener.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • start

        public void start()
        Starts the execution of Runnable objects. Does nothing if the execution has started.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • waitForFinished

        public void waitForFinished()
        Blocks the execution until all threads are finished.
        Since:
        1.0.0
